title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Sept. 10)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: In Abington, recent home sales include a 2,090-square-foot Colonial for $622,500 and a 976-square-foot conventional home for $425,000.
Acton saw a condo town house at 123 Skyline Drive sold for $860,000 and a Colonial on 50 Seminole Road for $850,000.
In Arlington, notable sales include a 2,480-square-foot Garrison for $1,335,750 and a 1,570-square-foot Colonial for $1,066,000.

title: Here’s who will be on the ballot for November’s 2025 City Council election
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Candidates for Boston's City Council election were narrowed down through a preliminary election on September 9, 2025.
Ruthzee Louijeune leads the at-large city councilor race with 17.65% of votes in a competitive field of eight finalists.
District races featured significant leads, with Gabriela Coletta Zapata securing 76.96% of votes for District 1.

title: Mayoral preliminary: Wu maintains huge lead over Kraft as both advance to November election
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Michelle Wu advances to November general election, leading Josh Kraft by over 45 percentage points in Boston's mayoral preliminary.
Josh Kraft, despite a significant loss, vows to campaign harder as he progresses to the general election against Wu.
Voter turnout for the preliminary was nearly 18%, with over 75,000 ballots cast, lower than 2017's 27.8% turnout.

title: What to know about the viral surrogacy lawsuit
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Cindy Bi, a San Francisco venture capitalist, sued surrogate Rebecca Smith after a miscarriage, claiming it was intentional.
Smith moved and changed jobs due to harassment from Bi; Bi contacted FBI and her new employers, Wired reported.
Bi's lawsuit appeals continue after a judge ruled against her; Smith faces medical bills and filed a restraining order.

title: A healthy Hampus Lindholm could change Bruins’ fortunes in several areas
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Hampus Lindholm returns to Boston Bruins training camp healthy after missing 65 games last season with a fractured patella.
Lindholm, a key defenseman, aims to boost the Bruins' stability and offensive capabilities, including their struggling power play.
The Bruins had a disappointing 33-39-10 record last season, partially due to Lindholm's absence, but hope for a bounce-back year.

title: Drake Maye receives a ringing endorsement from Bills QB Josh Allen
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bills QB Josh Allen praised Patriots QB Drake Maye as talented and authentic on the 'Like a Farmer' podcast.
Maye, a second-year quarterback, was drafted No. 3 in 2024 and is compared to Allen for arm strength and mobility.
In Week 1, Maye completed 30-of-46 passes for 287 yards with a touchdown and interception against the Raiders.

title: MBTA debuts train design to honor historic New England railroad, with more on the way
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: The MBTA debuted a Boston and Maine Railroad train with vintage maroon and yellow design on the Commuter Rail.
Two additional trains honoring New Haven and New York Central Railroads will be introduced by the end of the year.
The refurbished trains include modern upgrades like remote monitoring, diagnostics, and enhanced brake and control systems.

title: Patriots could be facing off against their former 1st-round pick in Miami
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Cole Strange, a former Patriots first-round pick, is signing with the Miami Dolphins from the Browns' practice squad.
Strange played three seasons with the Patriots, starting 29 games, but faced injuries and was ultimately released.
Miami seeks to strengthen their offensive line after an injury to starting right guard James Daniels in Week 1.

title: Tufts to go tuition-free for families making less than $150K
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Tufts University will offer tuition-free education for families earning less than $150,000 starting next fall.
Families earning under $60,000 will receive financial aid packages excluding student loans, including grants and work-study options.
The Tufts Tuition Pact is funded by donors and aims to increase financial aid to over $143 million for fiscal year 2026.

title: Aunt now caring for young daughter of parents killed in Watertown murder-suicide
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Karine Asatryan and David Minasvand were killed in a murder-suicide in Watertown, leaving their 1-year-old daughter orphaned.
The couple's daughter, Madeline, will be cared for by her aunt, Meline Asatryan, who is organizing a fundraiser for her.
Over $37,000 has been raised to support Madeline's needs, covering baby supplies, medical care, childcare, and future education.
